title: At the Freddie Mercury tribute in 1992, why did they include two David Bowie written songs (All the Young Dudes and Heroes) instead of more Queen stuff? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most of the artists at the tribute concert performed a couple of their own songs and a couple included one or two Queen ones. This all happened at the start of the concert, before Queen came on. I’ve attached a set list. Various Artists Setlist at Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert 1992 The main difference with the Bowie section is that he did his part within the Queen section, and was the only guest singer to do his own songs in their set. Looking at the set, these songs seem to be added to what looks like a very typical Queen set. So it isn’t that other songs were necessarily taken out, but these were added in. In context, Dudes is a song that was around when Queen and Bowie were first popular, and given the inclusion of the big names of Ronson and Hunter on stage with Bowie, it would have been unthinkable to do this performance prior to the main set. “Heroes” having become a Bowie signature song is his only solo song included (I know he wrote Dudes, but he didn’t have a hit with it, and it’s associated more with MTH), and given the theme of love against oppression it fitted well with the set. Bowie and the members of Queen knew each other well. I believe Bowie and Taylor were especially friends. Having played the same venues and gigs, Top of the Pops shows and, as they said, slept with a lot of the same people, it made perfect sense for a short Bowie section to be included, after the performance of Under Pressure. As a slight aside, one thing I never understood, having seen both Bowie and Queen several times, is why they didn’t do Under Pressure at Live Aid, when they were both there. But that, of course, is another question.

I think that Dave Heaton is correct in that the Bowie written song “All the Young Dudes” was more in homage to Mott the Hoople who gave Queen an important break by giving them support slots in their first tours of the US and UK. It was Mott the Hoople who had a number #3 hit with David’s song before breaking up in 1974. Since they were not among the more current and popular acts it made sense to include Bowie in the performance with Ronson and Hunter. Queen got along well with Mott the Hoople and they remained friendly despite the fact that by the end of the tours Queen were viewed as stealing the show and some said they began as MTH tours but ended as Queen tours. At one point Ian mentored Freddie who had stage fright and was despondent after a show that didn’t go over as well as usual. There have also been some collaborations with Brian, Roger and Freddie providing back up vocals on their songs and Brian has played guitar for Ian. Nice of the band to remember them and include them in the FM Tribute Concert. It was said that acts were chosen according to their relevance to Freddie so that’s the relevance. Freddie and Ian years later.

Bowie brought Ian Hunter and Mick Ronson out as Queen were given their first support slots, in both the UK and US by Hunter’s band, Mott The Hoople. Ronson was a member of both Mott and Bowie’s band. So, as far as I can guess, … Dudes was done as a reminder that Queen and Mott had been friends for many years and Mott had given them their big break. Heroes was lyrically appropriate for the occasion: “We can be Heroes, Just for one day…”. By the way, this was Ronson’s last public appearances before he was diagnosed with cancer, from which he subsequently passed away in 1993.

Queen toured as support to Mott the Hoople so it was a nice nod to their past with All The Young Dudes……and Heroes is just a great song…..I was there that day and for me was the best song that day…..amazing to see Mick Ronson play that day as well .
